text: Don't trust her analysis of the budget; she failed high school math.
explanation: Attacks the person, not the reasons.

text: You want a smaller marketing budget, so you must want zero customers.
explanation: Exaggerates the original claim to attack it.

text: Either we adopt this tool today or our project will fail.
explanation: Presents only two options when others exist.

text: A famous actor says this vitamin cures colds, so it works.
explanation: Authority is not relevant evidence.

text: If we allow snacks at desks, soon no one will work at all.
explanation: Predicts extreme outcome without supported steps.

text: Her past mistakes don't prove this claim false; let's check the data.
explanation: Focuses on reasons, not the person.

text: Dr. Martinez's research is unreliable because she's been married three times.
explanation: Personal life has no bearing on research quality. This attacks the researcher instead of evaluating the research methodology or findings.

text: Security advocates want to destroy the economy and force everyone to live in caves.
explanation: Grossly exaggerates environmental positions. Most environmentalists advocate for sustainable practices, not returning to pre-industrial life.

text: Either we ban all social media or kids will never learn to communicate face-to-face.
explanation: Ignores middle-ground solutions like time limits, age restrictions, educational programs, or supervised usage.

text: This investment strategy works because my successful cousin recommended it.
explanation: Being successful in one area doesn't make someone a financial expert. No evidence of actual investment expertise is provided.

text: If we allow students to retake one exam, soon they'll demand to retake everything and grades will become meaningless.
explanation: Assumes inevitable escalation without justification. Policies can have clear boundaries and exceptions without total collapse.

text: The new software reduced processing time by 40% in controlled tests, so it will likely improve our workflow efficiency.
explanation: This is a sound inductive argument. Empirical evidence from controlled tests provides reasonable grounds for predicting similar results in practice.

text: We shouldn't trust Karen's safety proposal since she's always complaining about everything.
explanation: Dismisses the proposal based on personality traits rather than evaluating its merits. A complainer could still identify genuine safety issues.

text: Access-control advocates want to confiscate every weapon and leave law-abiding citizens defenseless against criminals.
explanation: Misrepresents most gun control positions, which typically focus on background checks, waiting periods, or specific weapon types, not total confiscation.

text: You're either completely committed to this project or you don't belong on this team.
explanation: Ignores degrees of commitment and different ways to contribute. Someone could have valid concerns while still being a valuable team member.
notes: Binary thinking about complex human relationships

text: This diet pill works because it was featured on a popular morning show.
explanation: TV shows prioritize entertainment and ratings over medical expertise. Being featured on TV doesn't constitute scientific validation.
notes: False authority - media coverage ≠ medical approval

text: If we start working from home one day a week, eventually nobody will come to the office and the company culture will completely collapse.
explanation: Assumes escalation without evidence. Many companies successfully implement hybrid policies without losing company culture entirely.
notes: Ignores management controls and employee motivation

text: Since the last three product launches exceeded sales projections, the marketing team's strategy appears to be effective.
explanation: Sound inductive reasoning based on consistent evidence. Multiple successes provide reasonable grounds for concluding the strategy works.
notes: Pattern recognition with adequate sample size

text: Don't listen to Professor Johnson's lecture on economics—he drives an old, beat-up car.
explanation: Personal financial choices don't invalidate academic expertise. A professor might choose an old car for environmental, practical, or personal reasons.

text: People who want policy reform obviously think all criminals should be released immediately without consequences.
explanation: Mischaracterizes reform positions, which typically focus on rehabilitation, sentencing guidelines, or addressing systemic issues, not eliminating consequences.

text: We must either cut all project spending or face complete economic collapse.
explanation: Ignores gradual adjustments, targeted cuts, revenue increases, or mixed approaches. Most economic policy involves nuanced combinations of strategies.
notes: Extreme binary choice in complex domain

text: This cryptocurrency is a good investment because a famous athlete endorsed it on social media.
explanation: Athletic expertise doesn't translate to financial expertise. Celebrity endorsements often involve paid promotions rather than genuine investment advice.
notes: Irrelevant authority with potential conflicts of interest

text: If we allow employees to leave 15 minutes early on Fridays, soon everyone will expect to work part-time schedules.
explanation: Assumes uncontrolled escalation. Specific, limited policies can exist without inevitably expanding. Management retains discretion over different requests.
notes: Assumes policy boundaries cannot be maintained

text: The medication reduced symptoms in 85% of patients during clinical trials, suggesting it will be effective for most people with this condition.
explanation: Sound statistical reasoning. Clinical trials provide systematic evidence, and 85% effectiveness rate gives reasonable basis for predicting individual outcomes.

text: This restaurant's new menu can't be good because the chef used to work at a fast-food chain.
explanation: Past employment doesn't determine current abilities. Many skilled chefs have diverse backgrounds, and the menu's quality should be judged on its own merits.
notes: Career history irrelevant to current performance

text: All the reports show declining crime rates over the past five years, so the new policing strategies appear to be working.
explanation: Sound reasoning from consistent data trends. While other factors might contribute, sustained improvement provides reasonable evidence for policy effectiveness.
notes: Appropriate causal inference from sustained trends

text: We shouldn't accept his report on city planning; he doesn't even live in the city.
explanation: Attacks where the person lives instead of evaluating the report’s content.

text: Ignore Linda's ideas about time management; she's always late to meetings.
explanation: Dismisses the argument by pointing to the arguer’s tardiness.

text: Her advice on nutrition is worthless because she eats fast food sometimes.
explanation: Attacks personal habits rather than addressing the merits of the advice.

text: He criticizes the pricing policy, but he hasn't filed his taxes on time for years.
explanation: Points to personal behaviour rather than addressing his argument.

text: Don't believe John's take on energy policy; he drives an old, gas-guzzling truck.
explanation: Irrelevant to whether the policy points are correct.

text: Her past mistakes don't automatically invalidate her current argument; evaluate the logic on its merits.
explanation: Encourages judging arguments on substance rather than personal history.

text: People who want to reduce security testing budget just want to leave the company defenseless.
explanation: Misrepresents calls for moderate cuts as calls for no defense at all.

text: Proponents of renewable energy want us to go back to the Stone Age.
explanation: Grossly distorts the position of renewable energy advocates.

text: Those who propose a curfew think the city should be under martial law.
explanation: Exaggerates a narrow proposal into an extreme position.

text: If you support background checks, you want to ban all firearms.
explanation: Distorts a moderate gun-control proposal into a total ban.

text: Advocates of data privacy want criminals to hide more easily.
explanation: Misrepresents privacy advocates’ intent as helping criminals.

text: Clarifying the original proposal before critiquing prevents misrepresentation.
explanation: Encourages strong-man rather than straw-man engagement.

text: Either you are part of the solution or part of the problem.
explanation: Ignores neutrality and middle-ground contributions.

text: If we can't hire a full-time specialist, we may as well abandon the initiative.
explanation: Ignores hybrid or part-time staffing options.

text: Either we automate everything or we remain stuck in inefficiency.
explanation: False choice between extremes; ignores gradual automation.

text: You either agree with every point or you are against us.
explanation: Forces a binary choice in a multi-faceted discussion.

text: You must choose between high profits and ethical practices.
explanation: Creates a false conflict between profitability and ethics.

text: Decisions are rarely either-or; often a spectrum of options exists.
explanation: Highlights that most choices allow for compromise or hybrid solutions.

text: This software must be secure; a celebrity entrepreneur tweeted about it.
explanation: A celebrity’s opinion is not relevant evidence for software security.

text: My neighbor, who's a lawyer, says this supplement cures migraines.
explanation: Expertise in law does not confer medical authority.

text: An online influencer recommends this investment; it must be safe.
explanation: Influence doesn’t equate to financial expertise.

text: A popular fitness blogger insists this diet prevents cancer.
explanation: Fitness blogging doesn’t confer oncology expertise.

text: A famous musician said meditation cures depression, so it's medically proven.
explanation: Musical fame does not make one a mental-health authority.

text: Citing a peer-reviewed study by experts in the field is relevant authority.
explanation: Proper expertise and evidence make for a valid appeal.

text: If we permit phones during lunch breaks, soon no one will put them away all day.
explanation: Predicts runaway usage without evidence of escalation.

text: If we give one project extra budget, every team will demand the same and bankrupt us.
explanation: Assumes uncontrollable escalation of exceptions.

text: Allowing remote work one day a week will lead to everyone working from home permanently.
explanation: Assumes incremental flexibility inevitably reaches extremes.

text: If students choose their own reading material, they'll eventually stop reading altogether.
explanation: Assumes a policy will spiral without showing causal links.

text: If we allow personal devices at work, the entire company will become addicted to drugs.
explanation: Expects total collapse without showing intermediate steps.

text: Implementing flexible policies with clear limits doesn't inevitably lead to extremes.
explanation: Shows how boundaries prevent escalation.

text: Ignore his scheduling proposal; he dresses too casually.
explanation: Attacks appearance, not the proposal’s merits.

text: People asking for code reviews just want to slow releases to a crawl.
explanation: Misrepresents the goal of quality checks as obstruction.

text: We can ship a smaller feature set now and add the rest next sprint.
explanation: Shows a middle path rather than a false either–or.

text: Allowing one flexible exception doesn’t require approving all future exceptions.
explanation: Bounded policies prevent the feared cascade.

text: Everyone in our industry is switching to Nimbus CRM, so it must be the best choice.
explanation: Popularity is not evidence of superiority.

text: Thousands of five-star reviews prove this supplement works.
explanation: Reviews show popularity, not clinical efficacy.

text: All my teammates adopted the new framework, so we should migrate immediately.
explanation: Team adoption is not proof of fitness for your use case.

text: Most investors are buying this stock today; it must be undervalued.
explanation: Crowd action does not demonstrate intrinsic value.

text: The whole city uses this rideshare app, so it’s the safest option.
explanation: Usage volume ≠ safety evidence.

text: Since most colleagues skip code reviews, they must be a waste of time.
explanation: Majority behavior is not a quality argument.

text: Three independent benchmarks show Nimbus CRM reduces support tickets by 25%.
explanation: Cites evidence, not popularity.

text: A meta-analysis of clinical trials shows no effect beyond placebo for the supplement.
explanation: Evidence-based conclusion.

text: We shouldn’t discuss the budget overrun; what matters is how inspiring our mission is.
explanation: Shifts away from the budget question.

text: Why debate the drug’s safety when hospital food is terrible?
explanation: Introduces an irrelevant topic to distract.

text: Instead of addressing the outage, let’s talk about our great culture awards.
explanation: Diverts from the original incident question.

text: Critics say the ad misleads, but our brand has supported charities for years.
explanation: Charity is irrelevant to the charge of misleading content.

text: The proposal might be late, but did you see the client’s rude email?
explanation: Email tone distracts from the lateness issue.

text: You asked about safety certification, but first, look at our stylish design.
explanation: Design is unrelated to safety certification.

text: Before discussing culture awards, we need a root-cause report for the outage.
explanation: Returns to the original question.

text: Charitable donations do not address whether the ad’s claim is true.
explanation: Separates relevance from distraction.

text: After we installed new lights, sales rose, so the lights caused the jump.
explanation: Correlation alone does not show causation.

text: Our servers crashed after the patch; therefore the patch is the reason.
explanation: Temporal order ≠ causal proof.

text: Every time I carry my lucky mug, the meeting goes well. The mug causes success.
explanation: Mistakes coincidence for causation.

text: Cities with more Wi-Fi have higher crime, so Wi-Fi increases crime.
explanation: Likely confounders; correlation not causation.

text: Our diet plan worked because weight dropped the same month we launched it.
explanation: Other factors may explain the change.

text: Accidents increased after the new signage; therefore signage is dangerous.
explanation: Needs analysis beyond timing.

text: A controlled A/B test isolating the lighting change showed no sales effect.
explanation: Uses proper causal evidence.

text: Crash logs implicate a driver bug introduced in the patch; rollback removes the error.
explanation: Direct evidence for causation.

text: Nearly every department switched to the new planning app, so it’s the smartest choice.
explanation: Appeal to popularity. Adoption rates don’t prove optimality for your needs.

text: Thousands registered for the webinar, so the method must be effective.
explanation: Popularity is not evidence of efficacy.

text: Competitors price at 9.99, so that price is optimal for us too.
explanation: Copying the crowd assumes they’re right without evidence for your context.

text: The forum agrees this library is fastest, so it is fastest.
explanation: Consensus on a forum is not a benchmark result for your workload.

text: Millions hold this fund, so its risk must be low.
explanation: Ownership counts don’t determine volatility or drawdown risk.

text: Everyone at the gym uses resistance bands, so they’re superior to weights.
explanation: Majority behavior doesn’t establish comparative effectiveness or suitability.

text: Most coworkers stay late, so staying late must be necessary.
explanation: Frequency of a practice doesn’t show necessity or efficiency gains.

text: Top schools use this rubric, so it’s the best measure of learning.
explanation: Prestige adoption isn’t proof of validity across contexts or subjects.

text: Most engineers prefer dark theme, so dark theme increases productivity.
explanation: Preference data isn’t performance evidence without controlled comparisons.

text: Benchmarks on varied workloads show the library reduces build time meaningfully.
explanation: Sound: cites controlled performance measurements rather than popularity claims.

text: A randomized trial found the program improved memory recall versus placebo.
explanation: Sound: randomized evidence supports the claim instead of social proof or trends.

text: Volatility and drawdown statistics, not holder counts, determine portfolio risk.
explanation: Sound: appeals to risk metrics rather than the crowd’s behavior.

text: We can’t discuss the missed deadline; let’s celebrate the new logo instead.
explanation: Red herring. Shifts attention from the deadline issue to branding celebration.

text: You asked about safety tests, but notice the device’s sleek finish.
explanation: Red herring. Aesthetic appeal is irrelevant to safety certification status.

text: Instead of the budget variance, consider our inspiring mission statement.
explanation: Red herring. Mission inspiration doesn’t address the variance question.

text: Why talk about the outage when last quarter’s uptime was great?
explanation: Red herring. Past metrics distract from the current incident’s analysis.

text: The proposal arrived late, but our team volunteered last weekend.
explanation: Red herring. Community service doesn’t excuse or explain lateness reasons.

text: Training scores dipped, but the cafeteria menu improved a lot.
explanation: Red herring. Food changes are irrelevant to learning outcome declines.

text: You asked about side effects; let’s focus on patient praise quotes.
explanation: Red herring. Testimonials don’t answer safety questions about adverse events.

text: Sales fell, but our social media mentions skyrocketed.
explanation: Red herring. Mentions don’t speak to revenue drivers or losses directly.

text: Yes, the report has errors, yet the author is very experienced.
explanation: Red herring. Author experience doesn’t fix or analyze the identified errors.

text: Return to the question: Were security patches applied before deployment?
explanation: Sound: refocuses on the relevant issue instead of distractions.

text: Awards don’t determine whether the ad’s factual claim is accurate.
explanation: Sound: separates reputation from truth of the claim under review.

text: Customer anecdotes don’t answer whether the trial met its endpoints.
explanation: Sound: demands outcome data relevant to the original question, not tangents.

text: After the office plant arrived, morale rose; the plant caused it.
explanation: False cause. Temporal correlation doesn’t prove causation; many factors affect morale.

text: The app crashed after I updated fonts, so the font change broke it.
explanation: Post hoc fallacy. Sequence alone doesn’t establish a causal link to fonts.

text: Cities with more libraries have more theft, so libraries increase theft.
explanation: Confounding likely. Population size or density can drive both variables independently.

text: We launched ads and sales grew; ads caused all the growth.
explanation: Over-attribute causation without controls or counterfactuals for seasonality or price changes.

text: I drank ginger tea and my cold faded; the tea cured it.
explanation: Anecdote and natural recovery mistaken for causation without controlled evidence.

text: Investors bought after my post, so my account moves markets.
explanation: Assumes causation from timing; ignores broader market drivers and randomness.

text: Productivity dropped after flexible seating; the chairs are to blame.
explanation: Post hoc. Other changes or regression to the mean could explain the drop.

text: The alarm sounded before the failure; the alarm caused the failure.
explanation: Confuses indicator with cause; alarms often precede faults by design.

text: Students who use calendars get higher grades, so calendars create intelligence.
explanation: Conflates correlation with causation; conscientiousness may drive both habits and grades.

text: Interrupted time-series analysis attributes the uplift to seasonality, not the ad.
explanation: Sound: employs a causal design to separate timing effects from advertising impact.

text: Crash dumps trace a null pointer introduced by the font parser change.
explanation: Sound: direct technical evidence links the change to the failure mechanism.

text: Randomized assignment of seating showed no effect on output.
explanation: Sound: randomized controls test causation rather than relying on sequence alone.

text: Our app is superior because it’s the best in its class.
explanation: Circular reasoning. Conclusion restates the premise using synonyms without support.

text: The policy is fair because it’s equitable.
explanation: Circular reasoning. Uses equivalent terms instead of reasons or evidence of fairness.

text: This method is reliable because it never fails.
explanation: Begging the question. The premise assumes the very reliability in dispute.

text: The diet works because it’s effective.
explanation: Tautology. Repeats the claim without offering independent support or data.

text: The model predicts accurately because it’s precise.
explanation: Equivocation. Precision and accuracy are asserted, not demonstrated with validation results.

text: We should trust the roadmap because it’s trustworthy.
explanation: Circular. The conclusion is smuggled into the premise with no new grounds offered.

text: The course is valuable because it’s worth taking.
explanation: Begging the question. Value is asserted by rephrasing, not by evidence or outcomes.

text: The investment is safe because it’s low-risk.
explanation: Circular definition. Safety is assumed by labeling without risk metrics or history.

text: The patch is necessary because it’s required.
explanation: Circular. “Required” just repeats “necessary” without justification like fixes or compliance.

text: Adopt the policy because controlled trials reduce processing time significantly.
explanation: Sound: gives external evidence for the claim rather than restating it circularly.

text: Trust the model because cross-validation shows low out-of-sample error.
explanation: Sound: independent validation supports the conclusion without circularity.

text: Approve the patch because it fixes a reproducible crash in testing.
explanation: Sound: cites a concrete effect demonstrated under test, not a rephrased claim.

text: You can’t advise sleep hygiene; you stayed up late yesterday.
explanation: Tu quoque. Attempts to dismiss advice by pointing to the speaker’s inconsistency.

text: Don’t lecture me on punctuality; you’re often late yourself.
explanation: Tu quoque. Hypocrisy doesn’t show the norm or claim is false or useless.

text: Your budgeting tips are invalid; you once overdrafted.
explanation: Tu quoque. Personal history doesn’t refute the reasoning or evidence offered now.

text: We can ignore code style because you broke the guide last week.
explanation: Tu quoque. Points to past behavior instead of addressing code quality reasons.

text: Your presentation advice is worthless; your last talk had typos.
explanation: Tu quoque. A flawed exemplar doesn’t invalidate correct guidance or principles.

text: You can’t warn about screen time; you use your phone constantly.
explanation: Tu quoque. The claim’s truth isn’t determined by the claimant’s habits.

text: Your quality critique fails because your last release had bugs.
explanation: Tu quoque. Attempts to discredit criticism by citing past imperfection, not reasons.

text: Your nutrition talk is invalid; you ate cake at lunch.
explanation: Tu quoque. Inconsistency doesn’t show the dietary recommendation is false or harmful.

text: Your safety reminder is void; you forgot PPE once.
explanation: Tu quoque. Past lapse doesn’t refute the safety rule’s validity now.

text: An argument’s validity doesn’t depend on the speaker’s consistency.
explanation: Sound: separates truth evaluation from the arguer’s personal behavior or hypocrisy.

text: Even inconsistent messengers can present correct evidence; assess the reasons.
explanation: Sound: focuses on evidence quality rather than personal consistency attacks.

text: Enforce code standards based on maintainability data, not personal habits.
explanation: Sound: grounds the policy in outcomes and evidence, not tu quoque reasoning.

text: Have you stopped misreporting your hours?
explanation: Loaded question. Presupposes that hours were misreported, forcing a concession either way.

text: Which of your shortcuts caused the outage?
explanation: Loaded question. Assumes shortcuts existed and caused the outage without evidence first.

text: Why are your lectures always boring?
explanation: Loaded framing. Smuggles the assumption that all lectures are boring into the question.

text: How often do you ignore safety checks?
explanation: Loaded question. Presumes neglect instead of neutrally asking whether it occurs at all.

text: When did you decide the budget was inflated?
explanation: Presupposes the budget is inflated rather than asking whether it is inflated first.

text: Why do you hide sugar in the meal plan?
explanation: Assumes concealment without establishing that sugar is hidden at all.

text: Which colleagues did you pressure to leave?
explanation: Presupposes coercion occurred, skipping the question of whether it happened.

text: When will you admit your product is a copy?
explanation: Frames guilt in the question, assuming copying before evidence is discussed.

text: How much of the dataset did you fabricate?
explanation: Assumes fabrication and asks for degree, biasing any answer toward guilt.

text: Did you record your hours accurately this week?
explanation: Sound: neutral question that doesn’t presuppose wrongdoing or force a concession.

text: What evidence links the outage to a specific change?
explanation: Sound: requests evidence without assuming a cause in the question itself.

text: How did you design blinding to prevent data fabrication?
explanation: Sound: asks about safeguards procedurally, not presuming misconduct occurred.

text: This herb is natural, so it’s safer than medicine.
explanation: Appeal to nature. Natural origin doesn’t guarantee safety or efficacy without evidence of dose and effects.

text: Analog watches are natural, so they’re more reliable than digital ones.
explanation: Labels something as natural to claim superiority without performance data or failure rates comparison.

text: Unfiltered water is pure, so it’s healthier.
explanation: Purity by nature claim ignores contaminants and microbiological risks measurable by tests.

text: Handwritten notes are natural, so they improve memory regardless of context.
explanation: Assumes naturalness ensures benefit independent of task demands or learner differences.

text: Untreated fabrics breathe naturally, so they outperform synthetics in all conditions.
explanation: Generalizes from ‘natural’ to universal superiority without property-based comparisons or testing across conditions.

text: Manual driving feels natural, hence safer than assisted driving.
explanation: Equates natural feel with safety without crash-rate or hazard-avoidance evidence.

text: Raw foods are natural, so they always provide better nutrition.
explanation: Assumes natural preparation is superior in every case, ignoring bioavailability and safety tradeoffs.

text: Open windows provide natural security, so alarms are unnecessary.
explanation: Appeal to nature. Natural ventilation doesn’t inherently provide protection against intrusion or hazards.

text: Unpainted wood is natural, so it requires less maintenance.
explanation: Claims natural state ensures durability without evidence on moisture, UV, or wear performance.

text: Purity doesn’t determine safety; dosage, contaminants, and evidence do.
explanation: Sound: evaluates risk and benefit using testable parameters rather than natural labels.

text: Select materials by properties and use case, not by whether they’re ‘natural’.
explanation: Sound: focuses on measurable performance and requirements, not nature-based rhetoric.

text: Compare cooking methods by nutrients retained and risks, not by labels.
explanation: Sound: grounds evaluation in measurable outcomes rather than ‘natural’ versus ‘artificial’.

text: That encryption library can’t be trusted; some hackers like it.
explanation: Guilt by association. Who uses a tool doesn’t determine its security properties or audits.

text: The technique is flawed; a failed startup promoted it.
explanation: Discredits by association instead of evaluating the method’s evidence or results directly.

text: Don’t read that textbook; a controversial blogger recommended it.
explanation: Rejects content because of an endorser, not because of content quality or accuracy checks.

text: This budgeting method is suspect; gamblers use similar systems.
explanation: Associative smear. Similarity of use doesn’t demonstrate invalidity in other contexts or designs.

text: Avoid the workout; influencers hype it.
explanation: Rejects by linking to a group rather than assessing safety, form, or outcome data.

text: Skip the collaboration tool; spammers also use it.
explanation: Association fallacy. Overlooks legitimate features because undesirable users exist elsewhere too.

text: That hiring practice is risky; a company with lawsuits used it.
explanation: Condemns by association rather than examining safeguards, context, and outcomes of the practice itself.

text: The protocol is unsafe because scammers mention it on forums.
explanation: Assumes mention by bad actors makes the protocol unsafe, ignoring technical analysis and proofs.

text: The time-tracking policy is bad; micromanagers love it.
explanation: Dismisses by linking to a disliked group rather than weighing benefits and costs directly.

text: Assess the library by audits and tests, not by who uses it.
explanation: Sound: evaluates on evidence and verification instead of associative reasoning errors.

text: A method’s merits depend on data and results, not endorsements.
explanation: Sound: shifts attention to measurable outcomes rather than associations or reputations alone.

text: Judge the policy by outcomes and safeguards, not by who likes it.
explanation: Sound: emphasizes impact evaluation rather than guilt-by-association dismissals.

text: One estimate is zero defects, another is one hundred; the truth is fifty.
explanation: Middle-ground fallacy. Assumes averaging claims yields truth without evidence on actual defects.

text: Some want strong encryption, others weak; half-strength must be best.
explanation: Assumes compromise determines correctness; ignores threat models and requirements analysis.

text: Some say stretch, others rest; splitting time evenly cures injuries.
explanation: Assumes midpoint is correct regardless of condition specifics or clinical evidence.

text: Between firing and a bonus, a small pay cut is automatically fairest.
explanation: Declares the compromise correct without assessing performance facts or incentives effects.

text: Design A and B conflict; combining them guarantees optimal UX.
explanation: Assumes blending opposites yields truth, ignoring usability testing or conflicts created.

text: Some call the project profitable, others a loss; break-even must be right.
explanation: Averages opinions rather than analyzing cash flows, assumptions, and sensitivity ranges.

text: Students want no homework; teachers want lots; moderate load is automatically best.
explanation: Declares compromise true without evidence on learning outcomes or constraints involved.

text: Some claim the food is spoiled; others say fine; mix plates to be safe.
explanation: Compromise doesn’t guarantee safety; correct answer may be one side entirely.

text: Some say release now, others in a quarter; ship in six weeks, therefore correct.
explanation: Picks the midpoint as truth without risk analysis or readiness criteria evidence.

text: Choose the estimate supported by data and models, not by averaging opinions.
explanation: Sound: grounds conclusions in evidence, not position balancing for its own sake.

text: Sometimes one side is wrong; weigh evidence rather than splitting differences.
explanation: Sound: acknowledges that truth isn’t guaranteed to lie between opposing claims.

text: Pick the design after usability tests, not by blending conflicting features.
explanation: Sound: uses empirical testing to decide, avoiding automatic compromises as truth proxies.

text: The market forecast must be accurate; otherwise we’ll lose funding.
explanation: Appeal to consequences. Stakes don’t determine the truth of a forecast’s assumptions or model.

text: Bugs can’t exist; admitting them would hurt morale.
explanation: Claims false because of undesirable outcomes, not because of defect evidence evaluation.

text: This diet is effective because failure would be discouraging.
explanation: Equates desirability of success with truth; discouragement doesn’t prove effectiveness claims true or false.

text: The safety report is correct since a recall would be expensive.
explanation: Cost implications don’t determine whether the report is accurate; tests do.

text: Our plan will succeed; if not, we’ll miss the bonus.
explanation: Assumes success because failure is costly, not because evidence predicts success probabilities.

text: The algorithm must be fair; unfairness would cause complaints.
explanation: Predicts bad outcomes if false, but that doesn’t prove the fairness claim true now.

text: The training works because the schedule is tight.
explanation: Infers truth from organizational needs rather than evidence of learning outcomes achieved.

text: The numbers are right; revising them would delay launch.
explanation: Launch timing consequences don’t determine whether figures are accurate or computed correctly.

text: The tool is secure since insecurity would be embarrassing.
explanation: Conflates reputational costs with truth about security; needs audits and tests instead.

text: Accuracy isn’t set by consequences; verify forecasts with backtesting.
explanation: Sound: evaluates predictive accuracy using evidence rather than desired outcomes or fears.

text: Assess safety by test results and failure rates, not recall costs.
explanation: Sound: focuses on empirical indicators of safety, avoiding consequence-based truth claims.

text: Bug reports are true or false regardless of morale; check repro steps.
explanation: Sound: determines truth by replication and diagnostics, not by motivational impact.
